d:entry.p: A standard for wireless networking software and hardware, developed by the IEEE LAN/MAN Standards Committee (IEEE 802). The standard includes 802.11a, 802.11b, 802.11g, and 802.11n.

Lists of permissions that specify which users may access a file, folder, or disk, and what operations each user is permitted to perform. For instance, a folder’s permissions determine whether a particular user can view the folder’s contents (read only), add files to the folder but not view its contents (write only), or both (read and write).

On Macintosh computers using Mac OS X, each person who uses the computer can have an individual account with a separate home folder. There are various account types, including user, administrator, group, and guest.

On Macintosh computers using Mac OS X, users can specify a password to control access to their user accounts. Account passwords are often referred to as “login passwords.” Other important passwords in Mac OS X include keychain passwords and the Master password.
See access control lists.

An application that comes with Mac OS X. The Address Book application lets you store information about your contacts, including name and title, phone numbers, and addresses, as well as email, iChat, and website information. Because Address Book is integrated with other Mac OS X applications, all the information in your address book is also available from Mail, iChat, and Safari.

On Macintosh computers using Mac OS X, each person who uses the computer can have an individual account with a separate home folder. At least one of the accounts must be an administrator account, with the ability to create, delete, and modify other accounts, install software, and change system settings. If a Mac OS X computer has only a single account, it is automatically the administrator account. Other account types include user, group, and guest.
On Macintosh computers using Mac OS X, the account password for the computer’s administrator account. Other important passwords in Mac OS X include keychain passwords and the Master password.

Apple Filing Protocol. A client and server protocol used by the Apple file service to share files and network services. AFP uses TCP/IP and other protocols to support communication among computers on a network.
AOL Instant Messenger, an online instant messaging application from AOL LLC (formerly America Online, Inc.).

Wireless network devices and software from Apple Inc. that enable a computer to connect cable-free to a network or the Internet. An AirPort system includes a router, called an AirPort Base Station, which is connected to a network. The base station shares its network connection by broadcasting a signal that is received by an AirPort Card or other wireless networking card located inside or attached to a computer. AirPort base stations include the AirPort Extreme Base Station and the AirPort Express Base Station.
Apple software that lets a computer on an AirPort network share an external hard disk connected to a USB port on an Apple Extreme Base Station.

A compact AirPort Base Station from Apple Inc. that provides a wireless Internet connection to up to ten computers. The AirPort Express Base Station includes AirTunes—software that lets a connected computer use iTunes to send music to up to three music systems. AirPort Express can connect to a USB printer that is made available automatically to all computers on the network through Bonjour technology. It can also be used to extend the range of an existing AirPort Extreme network.

An AirPort Base Station from Apple Inc. that provides a high-speed wireless Internet connection to up to 50 computers. It can also accommodate a wired Ethernet connection. The AirPort Extreme Base Station can connect to a USB printer that is made available automatically to all computers on the network through Bonjour technology.
An Apple application that lets a computer on an AirPort network use iTunes to send music wirelessly to up to three music systems.

A feature of the iPhoto application on Macintosh computers. An iPhoto album is a collection of photos you select from your iPhoto library and arrange in the order you want. You can create a standard album by choosing particular photos, or a Smart Album that’s automatically updated, based on criteria you choose, as your iPhoto library changes. You can include the same photo in several albums without making multiple copies of it.

On Macintosh computers, a small file with no content of its own that points to a document, folder, application, or device, usually in a different location. When you double-click the alias, the source item opens or starts up.
In computer graphics, the technique of minimizing distortion in text and graphics, smoothing out jagged edges when high-resolution elements are displayed at a lower resolution.
An Apple application for Macintosh computers. The Aperture application is used by many professional photographers in post-production work.

Apple Inc. is a technology corporation founded in California in 1976. Headquartered in Cupertino, California, Apple Inc.’s best-known products are the Macintosh personal computer, iPod portable music player, Mac OS, and iLife software including iTunes.
The Apple service and support program for Macintosh computers, iPod music players, and other products.
See Mail.
A remote control for use with Apple products, including Apple TV.

An Apple application that permits a user, such as a teacher or system administrator, to monitor from his or her Macintosh computer the activity of other users on their Macintosh computers on a network.

A scripting language built into the Mac OS. The AppleScript language consists of commands that can be used to automate repetitive or complex tasks within many applications, including Mail, Safari, iCal, and other applications.
File and print server software that worked with the AppleTalk networking software. The AppleShare application has been replaced by the Mac OS X Server application.
A set of software tools from Apple Inc. for computer networking. The AppleTalk networking system has been replaced by TCP/IP networking on Macintosh computers using Mac OS X.

A set-top box from Apple Inc. that wirelessly receives a video signal and plays it on any enhanced-definition or high-definition widescreen TV. Apple TV can play movies, TV shows, music, and podcasts from an iTunes library, as well as movie trailers from www.apple.com, and slideshows of digital photos from the computer. Apple TV can sync with a Macintosh computer using Mac OS X v10.3.9 or v10.4.9 or later, or a Windows-based computer using Windows XP Home or Professional (SP2) or Windows Vista. For more information, see the Apple TV webpage.

An Apple application that includes word processing, spreadsheet, graphics, and database applications. The original AppleWorks program ran on the Apple II family of computers. A later version of AppleWorks was created for Macintosh computers using Mac OS X. AppleWorks has been replaced by the iWork suite of applications.
The graphical user interface and visual theme of Mac OS X.
In Mac OS X, to either compress a file to reduce its size, or reinstall system software while keeping your files and user settings intact (“archive and install”).

In the Numbers spreadsheet application, arguments provide the values that a Numbers function needs to perform a task. For example, the following formula contains a function named SUM with a single argument (a range of cells) that adds the values in column A, rows 2 through 10: =SUM(A2:A10). The number and types of arguments vary for different functions.
A recorded spoken program, such as a book being read aloud. You can include audiobooks and other spoken programs in your iTunes library.

A software program that converts audio data into a form that can be processed by your computer’s sound card and played through the speakers. A computer’s audio driver must be compatible with its sound card. The Mac OS X audio driver is Core Audio.
A feature of Apple’s Safari web browser that automatically fills in forms on a webpage, using information from your address book and from forms you’ve previously filled in.

An application that comes with Mac OS X and lets you create workflows for automating repetitive tasks. Automator works with many other applications, including the Finder, Safari, iCal, Address Book, Microsoft Office, and Adobe Photoshop.
A DVD movie or slideshow that plays automatically when a viewer inserts the DVD into the computer’s optical drive. On Macintosh computers, you can create an autoplay DVD using the iDVD application.
A version of the UNIX operating system for certain models of Macintosh computers. The first version of the A/UX operating system was released in 1988, and the final version was released in 1995.
In Mac OS X, you can set a customized background in many places including the desktop, Finder windows, and iDVD projects. See also desktop picture and iDVD themes.

Apple software available to MobileMe members. The Backup application lets you set up automatic, regularly scheduled backups of the files on your Macintosh computer, including your photos, music, home folder, and more.

A small graphic that appears when you move the pointer over an image, window, icon, or other object. A badge overlay provides additional information about the object. In the Aperture digital photography application on Macintosh computers, when you apply adjustments, keywords, ratings, or other changes to an image, Aperture marks the image with a badge overlay. Badge overlays appear only onscreen, and not on printed copies.

Software built into Mac OS X. The Bonjour software connects a computer to nearby websites and devices such as printers and other computers. It also finds iChat buddies and shared information, such as shared music and photos, on a local area network.

An application that helps you find, display, and interact with text, images, sound, and other information. A web browser is used to navigate webpages on the Internet. The Safari application, used on Macintosh computers, is an example of a web browser.
A list, saved by Safari or another web browser, of the addresses of the webpages you’ve visited. A browsing history typically contains about a week’s worth of webpage addresses.

In instant message applications, a list of people you can select to chat with. Normally a buddy list contains the names of people most frequently contacted. A buddy list usually shows each buddy’s status (online and available, or unavailable).

A type of folder found on Macintosh computers using Mac OS X. A burn folder contains items that you want to burn to a CD or DVD. Double-clicking the burn folder’s icon and clicking the Burn button copies all items from the burn folder to the disc.
A calculator application that comes with Mac OS X. Calculator includes basic, scientific, and programmer modes and supports Reverse Polish notation.
Software that lets multiple users publish and subscribe to collaborative calendars, and synchronize them among multiple devices. The shared calendars are managed by a CalDAV server.

In input method software, the window used to enter characters, such as Chinese Kanji, that are not found on the keyboard. The candidate window appears when you enter an input code that has more than one character associated with it. You choose the character you want from the candidate window to enter it into text.

A set of tools called application programming interfaces (APIs) for software developers creating applications for the Mac OS. Carbon includes a user interface tool kit, event handling, the Quartz 2D graphics library, and multiprocessing support.

Compact disc database. CDDB is a licensed trademark of Gracenote, Inc. Software applications use the CDDB to look up audio CD information on the Internet. After querying the CDDB, an application can display the title, artist name, track list, and other information for most CDs.

In the Numbers spreadsheet application, cell references identify specific cells in formulas. You can create cell references using the letters and numbers of reference tabs or using header cell names. If your table has both a header row and a header column, you can identify a cell using the column name followed by the row name.

In the Numbers spreadsheet application, you can apply a format to a cell so that its value is displayed in a particular way. For example, you can format cells that hold monetary values so that a currency symbol (such as $, £, or ¥) appears in front of numbers in the cells. Or you can format cells to contain controls, such as checkboxes and sliders, which are used to add or change cell values.

An attachment to an electronic document that allows the safe transfer of information over the Internet. Web browsers, mail applications, and instant message applications use certificates to encrypt information exchanged with a secure site. Certificates protect your login information, credit card numbers, addresses, and other secure data. Certificates are issued by trusted organizations, such as VeriSign, Inc. or RSA Data Security, Inc. When you go to a secure website, Mac OS X checks the site’s certificate and compares it with certificates that are known to be legitimate. If the website’s certificate is not recognized, or if the site doesn’t have one, you receive a message.
Markers inserted into a digital movie to create a scene selection menu, so that viewers can go directly to specific scenes.

A feature of Mac OS X that lets you insert special characters, such as mathematical symbols, letters with accent marks, arrows and other “dingbats,” or characters from other languages, into your documents.

A feature of earlier versions of the Mac OS that let you connect to printers and servers, and turn AppleTalk networking on and off. Replaced in Mac OS X with the Print & Fax and Network panes of System Preferences.

A set of software tools from Apple Inc. that comes with Final Cut Pro, a professional video editing application. The Cinema Tools software is used to track the relationship between the original film and sound and its digitized video counterpart.
Earlier versions of the Macintosh operating system, replaced by Mac OS X.

A segment of audio or video. In the iMovie application, you can work with clips in several ways to achieve the effects you want, including moving clips around, setting the starting and ending points of music clips, adding transitions between clips, and more.

A set of tools called application programming interfaces (APIs) for software developers creating applications for the Mac OS. Cocoa is an object-oriented application environment for developing Mac OS X native applications. Cocoa applications follow Apple’s human interface guidelines, so their appearance and operation is familiar to Macintosh users.

A set of tools called application programming interfaces (APIs) for software developers creating iPhone and iPod touch applications. Cocoa Touch is based on the Cocoa tools for creating Mac OS X applications.

An Apple color-matching application. ColorSync integrates all imaging devices such as display screens, printers, scanners, and digital cameras so that the color viewed on a screen is the same as the color printed out. ColorSync is part of Mac OS X.

Information that the ColorSync application saves for all imaging devices attached to the computer, such as scanners, printers, and displays. The profile is used to reproduce images as accurately as possible. For example, when an image is scanned, the image file includes a copy of the scanner’s profile. When the image is printed, a matching process converts the color information from the scanner’s profile to the printer’s profile.
A type of disk drive. A combo drive can read and write (copy) to CDs, and read but not write to DVDs.

An access-control device. Passing a Common Access Card through a card reader permits you to log on to the computer, access the computer when the screen saver is on, make changes to certain System Preferences panes, and install software.

A feature that lets you format a cell on a Numbers spreadsheet so that the cell is displayed a particular way when a condition occurs. For example, you can make a cell’s background turn red when its value exceeds a particular number.

On Windows computers, the control panel contains small programs that let you select settings such as your desktop background or method for connecting to the Internet. On Macintosh computers, System Preferences are used to select settings.

Used in earlier versions of the Mac OS to view the battery status, check the network connection, change the system volume, adjust the display resolution, and perform other functions. In Mac OS X, menu bar menus replace the control strip.

A small file placed on your computer by a website to store information. When you return to the site later, your web browser sends back the cookies that belong to the site. The cookies tell the site who you are so the site can show you information that’s appropriate for you. Cookies can store information that identifies you, such as your name and email address. A website has access only to the information you provide. A website can’t use cookies to gain access to other information on your computer.
An audio driver used on Macintosh computers.

A feature of the Finder in Mac OS X version 10.5 Leopard, and of the iTunes media player. In iTunes, the Cover Flow feature displays on a computer screen the album art in an iTunes music collection, permitting quick browsing through the albums. In the Finder, the Cover Flow view is one of four options for browsing the files, folders, and applications displayed in a Finder window.
To edit an image, such as a photo, by keeping only the portion you like and removing the rest.

Apple software that comes with Mac OS X and provides small applications called “widgets.” Widgets have a wide variety of uses, such as checking stock prices, finding local or global weather information, looking up words in a dictionary, and so on.

A software development program from Apple that lets you create Dashboard widgets and web applications (webpages optimized for Safari on iPhone). Widgets and web applications created using Dashcode use standard web technologies such as Hypertext Markup Language (HTML), Cascading Style Sheets (CSS), and JavaScript.
The background area of a computer screen. A desktop provides icons, windows, toolbars, files, and folders that you can create, edit, move, and delete.
The color, pattern, or picture you use to customize the background area of your screen. You can choose a desktop picture using the Desktop & Screen Saver pane of System Preferences.
An application that comes with Mac OS X. Dictionary lets you look up definitions and synonyms in a variety of sources including the Oxford American Dictionaries and the Apple Dictionary.

Also known as a public key certificate, an electronic document that associates your digital identity with other information, such as your name, email address, or business. Web applications, such as the Safari web browser, Mail, and iChat, use certificates to provide safe transfer of information over the web.

A single file that contains the complete contents and organization of all files and folders on a storage device such as a hard disk or optical disk. You can use the Disk Utility program to create a disk image. With a disk image, you can archive old data, share files with others, encrypt sensitive information, and make copies of disks.
An application for performing disk-related tasks that comes with Mac OS X. Disk Utility lets you create disk images and mount, remove, reformat, partition, burn, and repair disks.

An application launcher that comes with Mac OS X. The Dock is located along the edge of the screen. It contains icons for many of the applications available on the computer, and you can drag icons to and from the Dock.

Originally a character in the Cairo dingbat (ornament) font, the dogcow was used to show the orientation and color of the paper in page setup dialogs on Mac computers. Over time the dogcow acquired additional spots and a more bovine appearance. The call of the dogcow is “moof.”
Part of the domain name of a computer that’s connected to the Internet. The name “www.example.com” consists of the subdomain or host name “www,” the domain “example,” and the top-level domain “com.”

Document Object Model. An interface that lets software programs access and update the content, structure, and style of documents, including webpages. The DOM for a webpage lists each element that appears on the webpage, including content, links, style specifications, and scripts (small programs), and specifies the order in which the elements appear on the page.
Navigation of a webpage based on the page’s Document Object Model (DOM).
Dynamic random-access memory. The most common type of memory used in personal computers. DRAM requires a new electrical charge every few milliseconds.

A feature of Mac OS X that lets you share DVD or CD discs on an Ethernet or wireless network. If another computer on your network doesn’t have an optical drive, you can let that computer use a disc in your computer’s optical drive. The computer with the optical drive must have Mac OS X v10.4.10 or later, or Windows XP or Windows Vista.

In input method software used to enter characters, such as Chinese Kanji, that are not found on the keyboard, turn on dynamic prompt to have characters appear automatically in the candidate window as you type.

The “education Mac”—a low-cost, all-in-one computer with a 17-inch display, based on a PowerPC G4 processor. Apple Inc. introduced the eMac computer in 2002 and discontinued it in 2006, replacing it with an iMac model.
A feature of the iPhoto application on Macintosh computers. Clicking the Enhance button while editing a photo brightens the photo or adjusts its contrast levels based on preset criteria.
See Encapsulated Postscript

Abbreviated EPS. A file format based on the PostScript language used for printing text and graphics. An EPS file contains a description of text and graphics that can be used by a printer, and can be copied and shared by multiple computers and applications.

Abbreviated EQ. An audio control that works like the treble and bass controls on a stereo, but with more power and flexibility. You use an equalizer to fine-tune specific frequencies of the sound spectrum to customize music for different genres, listening environments (different rooms in your home, for example), and output methods (such as speakers or headphones). In the iTunes application, you can adjust equalizer settings manually or choose from more than 20 presets of the most commonly used EQ settings.

The iMovie and iPhoto applications on Macintosh computers organize your video and photo libraries by Event. An Event groups videos or photos taken in a certain period of time, such as photos shot during an afternoon wedding or a Saturday beach outing. You can organize your videos and photos by merging and splitting Events, and by creating your own names for Events.
Exchangeable Image File; a specification for the image file format used by digital cameras.
See EXIF.

A feature of Mac OS X that lets you temporarily move windows out of the way or off the screen entirely, normally by pressing the F11 keyboard key. The Exposé feature helps you see particular windows or the desktop.

An expansion card available for computers, including portable Macintosh computers. Adding an ExpressCard to your computer lets you expand its capabilities. You can use an ExpressCard to connect hard drives, compact Flash card readers, and more. Macintosh portable computers use the ExpressCard/34.

A feature of Mac OS X System Preferences. If your computer is connected to multiple display devices, including TVs and projectors, you can set the Displays pane of System Preferences to display the image on your desktop as a continuous image across all the devices.
See parental controls.

A feature of Mac OS X that allows more than one user to stay logged in to a computer at a time. When fast user switching is turned on, available user accounts appear in a menu at the upper-right corner of the menu bar. You can switch to a different account by choosing it from the menu. The previous account remains logged in, with all the current applications and documents open, so you can quickly switch back.
An application that comes with Mac OS X for encrypting and protecting files on Macintosh computers.

A suite of Apple video editing applications that can be used to edit video from professional video equipment and from home digital video cameras. Final Cut products are used by professional and amateur videographers. Final Cut applications load and display video on a Macintosh computer where you can edit and process the video.

Part of the Mac OS. The Finder organizes and displays views of the files and folders on your computer and on any disks attached to your computer. The Finder also permits searching and managing information on disks.
A type of cable, connector, and software that allows a high-speed connection between two computers, or between a computer and a device attached to it, such as a digital video camera.

In the Pages word-processing and page-layout application, a picture, graphic, or other object that is fixed in a specific position on a page. A floating object’s position does not change when you add more text or other graphics to the page. See also inline object.

A font-management application that comes with Mac OS X. Font Book lets you preview and install fonts, group fonts into collections, activate or deactivate individual fonts or collections, and export fonts to another computer.

A mathematical expression that uses operations to derive a value. In the Numbers spreadsheet application, you can add a formula to a table cell to display a value derived from values in other table cells.
A series of video frames that make up part of a video clip or the whole clip. In the iMovie application, you can select and work with frame ranges.
An application that comes with Mac OS X. Front Row lets you browse movies, music, and photos on your computer using the Apple Remote.
In iPhoto, a way to view your photos that uses your entire screen rather than a portion of it.

In the Numbers spreadsheet application, a named operation you can include in a formula to perform a calculation or to manipulate data in a table cell. The Numbers application provides functions that perform common mathematical or financial operations, retrieve cell values based on a search, manipulate strings of text, or get the current date and time, for example. Each function has a name followed by one or more arguments enclosed in parentheses.
Part of the iLife suite of creativity applications from Apple Inc. GarageBand lets you create, perform, and record original music. For more information, see the GarageBand webpage.
A screen-capture application that comes with Mac OS X. Grab is used to make screen shots (pictures) of all or part of the computer’s screen.

A company that maintains a database of information about the contents of audio CDs. Gracenote provides software applications and data that permit the management and searching of digital media. Several computer software applications, including iTunes, use Gracenote’s compact disc database (CDDB).

On Macintosh computers using Mac OS X, a type of account that consists of one or more other user accounts. A group account (also called an “account group”) is used for setting privileges for files shared among two or more users. You can’t log in to a computer using a group account name as you can with most other user accounts.
Abbreviation for Global System for Mobile Communications, the most widely used standard for mobile phones.

On Macintosh computers using Mac OS X, a type of account you can create to let others use your computer temporarily, without creating a separate user account for each guest. A guest can log in to the computer without a password. You can use parental controls to manage a guest account. A guest can’t change other accounts, alter the computer’s settings, or log in remotely. Files a guest creates using a guest account are deleted when the guest logs out.

Globally unique identifier. A hexadecimal string that uniquely identifies a user account, group account, or computer list. Also used to provide user and group identity for access control list (ACL) permissions, and to associate particular users with group and nested group memberships. GUIDs are 128-bit values, which makes the generation of duplicate GUIDs extremely unlikely.
A partition scheme based on a globally unique identifier (GUID). On Intel-based Macintosh computers, Mac OS X can be installed only on disks with the GUID partition scheme.

Formerly known as Gimp-Print, a collection of open source printer software programs, including Printer PostScript Description (PPD) files, that’s part of Mac OS X. Use Gutenprint software if other software isn’t available for your printer, or if it seems that the printer’s software isn’t working properly.
Any of the plugs on a computer where devices, such as keyboards and printers, can be attached. Common hardware ports include USB, Firewire, and Ethernet.
See Mac OS Standard format.
See Mac OS Extended format.

A folder created for each user of a computer when the user’s account is first set up. The home folder isn’t actually named “Home”; its name is the same as the user’s short name as specified in the user account. If you are the only user of your computer, there is only one user account and one home folder. The home folder stores your documents, music, pictures, preference settings, and more.

An Apple application, first released in 1987 and discontinued in 2004. HyperCard was one of the first successful hypermedia applications. It was used to create databases, presentations, games, teaching aids, and more.

A programming language used with Apple’s HyperCard, first released in 1987 and discontinued in 2004. The audience for the HyperTalk language was primarily beginning programmers. HyperTalk programs (called “scripts”) are similar to written English.
A line of portable computers available from Apple Inc. between 1999 and 2006. iBook computers were intended for use in homes and classrooms. The iBook line was replaced by the MacBook in 2006.
An Apple application available for iPhone, iPod touch, and iPad, which lets you download and read e-books (electronic books in ePub format).

An Apple calendar application that comes with Mac OS X and lets you keep track of appointments and to-do lists. You can also use iCal to synchronize information between computers, phones, and other devices.

An Apple instant messaging application that comes with Mac OS X. Using iChat, you can exchange messages with MobileMe members as well as people using other instant messaging software such as AOL Instant Messenger (AIM), Bonjour, Google Talk, and Jabber.

A feature of the iChat application that lets you present files, photos, slideshows, and movies in an iChat video window. You control the presentation from your desktop while your buddies view it on theirs.
A symbol that represents an application, file, or folder.

Personal storage space on Apple’s Internet servers, available to MobileMe members. You can use your iDisk to host websites, store or back up documents, and share files with anyone who has an Internet connection.

An Apple application that lets you author custom DVDs containing movies and digital photos. iDVD includes professionally designed themes and templates. iDVD is part of the iLife suite of software. For more information, see the iDVD webpage.

A feature of the iDVD application on Macintosh computers. iDVD themes give menus in iDVD projects a professional look. Themes include a group, or “family,” of menus that use a unified set of design elements. A typical theme family includes layouts for the main menu of a project, the scene selection menu, and an “extras” menu.

A suite of Apple applications that provide tools for making music, movies, digital photos, custom DVDs, and websites. The iLife suite includes the GarageBand, iPhoto, iMovie, iDVD, iTunes, and iWeb applications. For more information, see the iLife webpage.
A line of desktop computers available from Apple Inc. iMac computers were introduced in 1998.
An Apple application that lets you upload pictures from digital cameras or scanners attached to your computer or connected to a network.
An iTunes playlist that’s been published to share with others.

An Apple application that lets you import digital video footage from a camera, edit the video, add sound and effects, and save it as a movie that can be published on a website or disk. iMovie is part of the iLife suite of software. For more information, see the iMovie webpage.
Abbreviated “IR.” A device that uses the infrared electromagnetic spectrum for wireless communications. Most Macintosh computers include an infrared port to receive signals from the Apple Remote.

Handwriting recognition technology built into Macintosh computers. Ink works with a graphics tablet and stylus attached to the computer. You write on the tablet and Ink translates the writing into typed words.
See Ink.

In the Pages word-processing and page-layout application, a picture, graphic, or other object that’s embedded in the text flow. An inline object’s position changes when you add more text or other graphics to the page. If you type more text above an inline object, it is pushed along as the text grows.
The menu used for switching between input methods, when more than one input method is being used on a computer.
An application that allows computer users to enter complex characters, such as Chinese, Japanese, and Korean characters, using a Western keyboard.

In software applications, a window that shows the current settings for selected text or graphics, and lets you quickly change the settings while viewing the results. Many Mac OS X applications use inspector windows, including Pages, Keynote, and Numbers.

A program that comes with Mac OS X. The installer program extracts and installs files out of “packages”—files with the extension .pkg appended to their names. Software for Macintosh computers using Mac OS X is typically available in the form of .pkg files.

A feature available in Mac OS X applications including Pages, Aperture, and Preview. For an image that has a simple one-color background, such as a person standing against a clear blue sky, Instant Alpha lets you remove the background so that the remaining portion of the image has a transparent background.
A program from Apple Inc. that developers can use to create graphical user interfaces for Mac OS X and iPhone applications.

An application that comes with Mac OS X. Internet Connect lets you start a dial-up, Ethernet (PPPoE), or Virtual Private Network (VPN) connection, or have your AirPort Base Station connect to the Internet. You can also use Internet Connect to manage connections to Bluetooth equipment such as printers.
A number that indicates the protocol a server on the Internet is using. Web servers normally use port 80.

In the Pages word-processing and page-layout application, and in other text-editing applications, formatting marks that you don’t normally see. Invisibles include tabs, paragraph marks, page and section breaks, spaces, and other formatting marks. You can adjust your preferences to show invisibles.

A tablet computer from Apple Inc. Instead of a physical keyboard or keypad, the iPad includes a Multi-Touch screen and virtual keyboard and buttons. The iPad runs the iOS (operating system) and many of the same applications as the iPhone and iPod touch.

A combination mobile phone, multimedia player, and wireless Internet device from Apple Inc. Instead of a physical keyboard or keypad, the iPhone includes a touchscreen and virtual keyboard and buttons. For more information, see the iPhone webpage.

An Apple application that lets you save digital photographs; organize your photos; and publish your photos on websites, disks, and printed albums. iPhoto is part of the iLife suite of software. For more information, see the iPhoto webpage.

A line of portable music players from Apple Inc. iPod players range in size from the iPod shuffle player to iPod players that support video playback. iPod players can import music from Apple’s iTunes Store and from CDs. They are designed to work with iTunes, an application available on both Macintosh and Windows computers.
A portable music player in the iPod product line from Apple Inc. The iPod classic offers the most storage space of the iPod models.
A portable music player in the iPod product line from Apple Inc. The iPod nano includes a touchscreen and an FM radio tuner.
The smallest portable music player in the iPod product line from Apple Inc.
A portable music player in the iPod product line from Apple Inc. The iPod touch features a touchscreen, and includes the Safari web browser.
See infrared receiver.
A digital camera from Apple Inc. A small version of the iSight camera is built into some Macintosh computers.
An application that comes with Mac OS X. iSync synchronizes data in iCal and Address Book with MobileMe and with devices including iPod portable music players, mobile phones, and handheld organizers.

An Apple application that comes with Mac OS X and lets you import music, podcasts, and video from CDs or from the iTunes Store; organize media into custom albums and playlists; and burn it onto disks or transfer it to an iPod or other media player. iTunes is also widely used on Windows-based computers.

An Apple application that lets you create and publish webpages without any knowledge of web programming languages. iWeb contains professionally designed templates for blogs and other pages, and permits dragging and dropping of media files such as photos and movies. iWeb is part of the iLife suite of software. For more information, see the iWeb webpage.

A suite of Apple productivity applications for creating and publishing documents and presentations. The iWork suite includes Keynote for creating cinema-quality presentations, Pages for word-processing, and Numbers for creating spreadsheets. For more information, see the iWork webpage.
An open source online instant messaging application.
The trademarked name for Mac OS X version 10.2, the third major release of the operating system for Macintosh computers.
A family of computer software products and specifications from Sun Microsystems for developing applications that can run on many different types of computers.
A scripting language often used on webpages to handle special effects and provide interactivity.
See Mac OS Extended format.

A special effect, named after the American documentarian Ken Burns, that creates motion over a still image so that the camera appears to be sweeping across the subject (panning), or drawing nearer or farther away (zooming). You can use the Ken Burns effect in the iMovie application.
A computer network authentication protocol that lets individuals communicating over a non-secure network confirm their identity with one another in a secure manner.
The part of an operating system that handles memory management, resource allocation, and other low-level services essential to the system.

A type of error that occurs when the core (kernel) of an operating system receives an instruction that’s in an unexpected format, or that it can’t process properly. A kernel panic may also occur when the operating system is unable to recover from other types of errors. A kernel panic can be caused by damaged or incompatible software or, more rarely, damaged or incompatible hardware.

An application that comes with Mac OS X. You can use Keyboard Viewer to see the layout of characters on your keyboard for your chosen language, and to see and type characters used in languages other than your chosen language.

A stored set of passwords. For example, one keychain might store application, server, and website passwords you use for your job, whereas another keychain might store all the passwords you use for online shopping. Keychains reduce the number of passwords you have to track.

The Apple password management system built into Mac OS X. A keychain stores all the passwords, keys, and certificates required for applications, servers, and websites. When you open an item or connect to a device that requires a password, the keychain provides it so you don’t have to type it.
A password used to lock and unlock a keychain. Your keychain password is the same as your login password unless you use Keychain Access to create a different password.

An Apple application for creating professional quality slideshow presentations. Keynote includes templates, themes, cinematic transitions, and animated text. Keynote is part of the iWork set of productivity applications. For more information, see the Keynote webpage.

A DVD that begins to play automatically, and plays continuously, after it’s inserted into a media player. You can create kiosk mode discs using iDVD, an Apple application that lets you author custom DVDs.
Trademarked name for Mac OS X version 10.5, the sixth major release of the operating system for Macintosh computers.

An icon used in Mac OS applications. In Finder, a lock icon indicates that a file or folder is password protected. In the Safari toolbar, a lock icon in the toolbar indicates that communications with the webpage will be encrypted. A lock icon is used in many other applications to indicate that a password must be entered in order to open an item or connect to a server.
Setting a movie or slideshow to replay as soon as it ends, and to repeat continuously. You can create looping movies and slideshows using iDVD, an Apple application that lets you author custom DVDs.
A suite of Internet services designed for users of Macintosh computers (pronounced “dot Mac”). Replaced by MobileMe.
An Apple computer, also known as a Macintosh computer. See also Macintosh.

A line of portable computers from Apple Inc. based on the Intel Core Duo and Intel Core 2 Duo processors. Introduced in 2006, the MacBook computer replaces the iBook G4 and the PowerBook series of computers.

A lightweight, portable computer from Apple Inc., based on the Intel Core Duo and Intel Core 2 Duo processors and featuring an optional solid-state hard drive. The MacBook Air weighs 3.0 pounds (1.36 kg), and is 0.76 inches (1.93 cm) at its thickest point and 0.16 inches (0.4 cm) at its thinnest point. Introduced in 2008.

A line of personal computers from Apple Inc. Introduced in 1984, the Macintosh computer was the first commercially successful personal computer to use a graphical user interface (GUI) and a mouse instead of a command-line interface.
The operating system for Macintosh computers.

A hard disk format, supported by Mac OS 8.1 and later, that increases the number of allocation blocks (storage units) on a disk from previous disk formats used by the Mac OS. This format allows more than 65,000 files on a hard disk. Mac OS Extended format optimizes the storage capacity of large hard disks by decreasing the minimum size of a single file. A Mac OS Extended volume can be “journaled,” which means that the operating system keeps a continuous log (journal) of the changes made to the files on the volume. This helps the operating system restore the volume to a usable state when a power failure or other problem interrupts the disk’s operation and damages files.
The hard disk format supported by Mac OS 8.0 and earlier.
The latest version of the Apple operating system. Mac OS X combines the reliability of UNIX with the ease of use of Macintosh.
A server platform that supports Mac, Windows, UNIX, and Linux clients out of the box, and provides a suite of scalable workgroup and network services with advanced remote management tools.
The standard TCP/IP (networking protocol) for Macintosh computers through version 7.5.1 of the Mac OS. It was replaced in 1995 by Open Transport.
An Apple email application that comes with Mac OS X.

A method of cropping an image by covering (“masking”) the portion of the image you want to retain. In the Pages word-processing and page-layout application, you can mask an image using a rectangle or a custom shape of your choosing.
In the Pages word-processing and page-layout application, a watermark, logo, or other background image that appears in the same spot on every page of a document.

A password that lets you access an account protected by FileVault. If a user forgets his or her password for a FileVault-protected account, an administrator can use the master password to access the account and change the FileVault password. If a master password is forgotten, there is no way to access FileVault-protected accounts, and the files and settings in them are lost.

In Pages and Keynote templates, a file you can replace by dragging your own file to it. You can recognize a media placeholder by letting the pointer rest over it; a help tag appears instructing you to drag your own file into its place.

A Mac OS X application that helps you transfer your files and important settings from an older Mac to a new one. To use Migration Assistant, both computers must use Mac OS X, and must be FireWire equipped or be connected to the same wireless network.

A feature of Mac OS X System Preferences. If your computer is connected to multiple display devices, including TVs and projectors, you can adjust settings in the Displays pane of System Preferences so that the entire image of your desktop is displayed on each device, rather than as a continuous image across all the devices.

A suite of Internet services from Apple Inc. for Macintosh computers, iPhone, iPod touch, and PCs. A MobileMe subscription automatically keeps your mail, contacts, and calendar up-to-date on all your devices. MobileMe also provides a suite of web applications that let you access your information using a web browser, share photos and movies, host a website, and use an iDisk for online file storage. For more information, see the MobileMe webpage.

A feature of the MobileMe suite of services from Apple Inc. With a MobileMe subscription, you can publish photos and movies from iPhoto and iMovie directly to your MobileMe Gallery on the Internet. You can add MobileMe Gallery photo albums and movies to any of your webpages. When a MobileMe Gallery photo album is updated, your website is updated automatically with the new content.
In iDVD, a diamond-shaped icon in the scrubber bar that marks the current position in the music or video you’re editing. You can drag the motion playhead, stopping wherever you like.
A hard disk format for disks used with Windows computers. You can use Disk Utility to format MS-DOS (FAT) disks for Windows computers.

Touchscreen interaction with a computer or other device. A touchscreen equipped with Multi-Touch recognizes multiple simultaneous “touch points.” This allows gestures with both hands and multiple fingers. Intuitive gestures, such as using two fingers or hands to zoom in or out, are a feature of Multi-Touch technology. The touchscreen built into the Apple iPhone uses Multi-Touch technology.
See NFS.

Network File System. A client and server protocol that uses Internet Protocol (IP) to allow remote users to access files as though they were local. NFS exports shared volumes to computers based on IP address, rather than user name and password.

An Apple application for creating spreadsheets. Numbers includes a simple interface for setting up tables, charts, maps, labels, and more. Numbers is part of the iWork suite of productivity applications. For more information, see the Numbers webpage.
Non-volatile random access memory. A type of memory that retains information when the computer’s power is turned off.
A networking protocol for Macintosh computers using versions of the Mac OS prior to Mac OS X.

Arithmetic operators perform arithmetic operations, such as addition and subtraction, and return numerical results. Comparison operators compare two values and return TRUE or FALSE. In the Numbers spreadsheet application, you can use operators in formulas to perform arithmetic operations and compare values.
A disc drive that can read data on optical discs, including CDs and DVDs. Optical drives include CD-ROM, CD-RW, DVD-ROM, DVD-RW, and Blu-ray drives.

A series of related files (templates, preferences, or other application-specific files), combined into a folder that looks like a single file. Software updates for Macintosh computers come in packages that are “unpacked” and then installed.

A file that contains a software package. A package file normally has an icon that looks like an opened package. You can also identify a package file by looking at its Info window: The Kind field contains the word “package.”

An Apple word-processing application that includes advanced typography features and professional templates for creating reports, invitations, newsletters, and more. Pages is part of the iWork suite of productivity applications. For more information, see the Pages webpage.
Trademarked name for Mac OS X version 10.3, the fourth major release of the operating system for Macintosh computers.

Computer settings that let an administrator control the applications and information accessed by other users. In Mac OS X version 10.5 Leopard, parental controls are set using the Parental Controls pane in System Preferences.

A subdivision of a hard disk. On Macintosh computers, you can choose how many partitions you want when you format a hard disk using Disk Utility. Each partition appears on your desktop as a separate disk.
A system that allows Macintosh computer users to quickly copy items from one computer to another, or to use one computer to access files and applications stored on another.

A feature of Mac OS X that lets you display documents on the web, or on a local area network, by dragging them into the Sites folder on your computer’s hard disk. The documents must be in HTML format.

An Apple application for taking photos with an iSight camera. Photo Booth features built-in effects that can be applied to photos, including tints and filters such as sepia, and image manipulation such as “stretch” and “fisheye.”

Computer software that lets you view and search a selection of photos. iPhoto includes a photo browser for projects such as books or slideshows, which shows thumbnails of the photos selected for inclusion.

Apple video compression software. The Pixlet codec (compression/decompression) software permits viewing of full-resolution high-definition movies on Macintosh computers using Mac OS X version 10.3 Panther or later.

In Pages and Keynote templates, an image you can replace by dragging your own image to it. You can recognize a placeholder image by letting the pointer rest over it; a help tag appears instructing you to drag your own file into its place.

In Pages and Keynote templates, text you can replace by dragging, pasting, or typing your own text over it. You can recognize placeholder text by clicking it; a single click highlights the entire block of text so that you can easily replace it.
In Apple’s iTunes music player, a list of songs or pieces of music to be played in sequence.
A program you can add to a software application to expand its capabilities. For example, you can add a media plug-in to a web browser to enable the browser to play multimedia content on webpages.
An audio or video broadcast available on the Internet that you can play on a portable device or computer, such as an iPod, iPad, or Mac.
An Apple application for recording, publishing, and distributing high-quality podcasts.

A number used as an address by a server to determine which application should receive data packets. Firewalls use port numbers to determine whether data packets are allowed to traverse a local network.

A line of portable computers available from Apple Inc. between 1991 and 2006. PowerBook computers were targeted for business and professional use. The PowerBook line was replaced by the MacBook Pro in 2006.
A line of personal computers available from Apple Inc. between 1994 and 2006, based on Motorola’s PowerPC microprocessors.
A microprocessor from Motorola Corporation. The line of Power Macintosh computers from Apple Inc. was based on the PowerPC microprocessor.

Postscript Printer Description file. A file that contains information about the capabilities of a particular printer model. The PPD file provides the controls you need to take advantage of special features such as multiple paper trays, special paper sizes, or duplex printing. The printer model you choose when you add a printer specifies the PPD file used with the printer.

A protocol for communication between two nodes on a network, used for connecting over serial cables, phone lines, cellular telephone networks, and more. PPP is commonly used for dial-up access to the Internet.
Point to Point Protocol over Ethernet. A network protocol that’s similar to PPP, but takes advantage of increased speed available on Ethernet networks.

Parameter random-access memory. A type of memory used in Macintosh computers to store system settings, including the selected startup disk, screen resolution, time zone, speaker volume, and other settings.
An Apple application that lets you view PDF files, images, text documents, and many other types of files on Macintosh computers using Mac OS X.

A collection of printers you can create so that your document automatically prints to the first available printer in the pool. In Mac OS X, you use the Print & Fax pane of System Preferences to set up a printer pool.
A one-on-one training program available to users of Macintosh computers, offered at Apple Retail Stores.
A set of rules that determines how data is sent back and forth between two applications.

A server that provides an indirect network connection. A computer connects to the proxy server and requests a connection to a network. The proxy then connects to the specified network. Proxy servers are often used to provide network security. In Mac OS X, you specify proxy server information using the Network pane of System Preferences.
Apple graphics software that comes with Mac Os X. Quartz provides fast window resizing and scrolling, and onscreen animation and other special effects.
Apple graphics software. QuickDraw has been replaced by Quartz in Mac OS X.
A previewing application that comes with Mac OS X version 10.5 Leopard. Quick Look lets you view a sample of a document, picture, movie, or other file without opening an application.
An Apple multimedia application that handles video, media clips, sound, text, animation, music, and several types of images on Macintosh computers.

Random-access memory. The part of a computer where the applications and files currently being used are kept. RAM is more quickly accessed than the other kinds of storage in a computer, such as the hard disk or a DVD. There are several types of RAM, including DRAM, NVRAM, PRAM, and SRAM.
An Apple program that lets you install Mac OS X on your computer from an installation disc in another computer’s optical drive. The two computers must be on the same Ethernet or wireless network.
Change the partitioning scheme of a disk. See also partition.
Software included with Intel-based Macintosh computers that enables them to run PowerPC applications.

A computer networking device that receives a network signal and forwards it to one or more computers, printers, and other devices. Routers commonly provide Internet connections to multiple users. The AirPort Extreme Base Station from Apple Inc. is an example of a router.

Abbreviation for Really Simple Syndication, an alternative way of viewing a webpage. Websites that change frequently, such as news sites, often have RSS views. An RSS page viewed through the Safari web browser presents the titles of new and recent articles in a list, showing a line or two of each article’s content. If Safari detects an RSS view for a website, an RSS button, which you click to view the feed, appears in the address bar. The term RSS is used interchangeably with feed, news feed, RSS feed, and XML feed.
A web browser from Apple Inc.

During safe sleep, the current state of the computer is saved on the hard drive, including open applications and open documents. This prevents your information from being lost if the computer is completely shut down during sleep, which could occur if the battery runs down or is replaced.

A name you choose for communicating with others online. A screen name can be your real name or a pseudonym. You use a screen name with the iChat application to send and receive instant messages online.

A feature of Mac OS X v10.5 Leopard that lets you connect to another computer on the network and display its screen on your computer. While you share the computer’s screen, you control everything that happens on that computer, such as opening documents or applications; opening, moving, or closing windows; and shutting off the computer.
A timeline bar below a video or audio clip that shows the position of the motion playhead.

Virtual memory that is encrypted for security. Because information stored on the hard disk remains until it is overwritten, you can reduce the risk that sensitive information is being left on your hard disk by using secure virtual memory.
A computer that provides services (such as file services, mail services, or web services) to other computers or network devices.
Digital effects software available from Apple Inc. and used for feature films, broadcasts, and interactive games.
A software tool that searched both local disks attached to a computer and pages on the web. The Sherlock tool was introduced by Apple Inc. with Mac OS 8.5.

The name that identifies an individual user account on Macintosh computers. When you create a user account, the short name is automatically generated based on the name you enter for the account. You can change the short name while you’re creating the account, but you can’t change it after the account is created.

The area on the side of Finder and application windows that displays buttons, links, icons, and other information. The Finder window’s sidebar displays icons for things you frequently use, including disks, servers, and folders.

A simplified version of the Mac OS X Finder with fewer menus and limited access to the items on the hard disk. Simple Finder restricts an account’s access to the files and applications on the computer.
In the iMovie and iPhoto applications, to move the mouse pointer slowly over the thumbnails within a video clip or Event to find a single frame or image.

A state in which a computer’s display is dimmed and its disk drive is shut down. When your computer is in sleep, it’s turned on but consumes less power. It takes less time to wake your computer from sleep than it does to start it up after being turned off.
An indicator light on your computer that pulses slowly when the computer is in sleep.

Self-Monitoring Analysis and Reporting Technology. Software that lets the computer’s startup program assess the condition of the computer’s hard disk. S.M.A.R.T. technology can warn you of impending drive failures so you can take preventative action, such as backing up your data.
A name or address that appears in a blue bubble in the address field of a message you’re sending.

A type of album (folder) used by the iPhoto application from Apple Inc. A Smart Album automatically finds photos that match one or more specified criteria. For example, you can create a Smart Album that contains pointers to photos taken in the month of October, or all photos labeled “Paris.”

A type of folder on Macintosh computers. A Smart Folder automatically finds items that match one or more specified criteria. For example, you can create a Smart Folder that contains pointers to all spreadsheets on a computer. The actual location of the files listed in a Smart Folder doesn’t change, so one item could be listed in many Smart Folders.
A collection of contacts that Address Book automatically updates with new contacts when the contacts fit criteria you specify.

A type of mailbox (mail folder) used by the Mail application on Macintosh computers. A Smart Mailbox automatically finds email messages that match one or more specified criteria. For example, you can create a Smart Mailbox that contains pointers to all messages from family members, or all messages on the subject “Hawaii.” The actual location of the email messages listed in a Smart Mailbox doesn’t change, so one item could be listed in many Smart Mailboxes.

A type of playlist (folder) used by the iTunes application from Apple Inc. A Smart Playlist automatically finds music that matches one or more specified criteria. For example, you can create a Smart Playlist that contains pointers to all jazz tunes, or all songs by a particular group.

Server Message Block. A protocol that allows client computers to access files and network services. It can be used over TCP/IP, the Internet, and other network protocols. SMB services use SMB to provide access to servers, printers, and other network resources.
A protocol for sharing access to files, printers, serial ports, and other information and devices between nodes on a network. Used primarily on Windows computers.

An orange button with a white arrow found at the right end of the location and search fields in Safari, a web browser from Apple Inc. When you click the SnapBack button, you return to a designated page or list of search results.
The trademarked name for Mac OS X version 10.6, the seventh major release of the operating system for Macintosh computers.
An application on Macintosh computers that checks for updates to software applications. Software Update can be set to automatically notify you when an update is found.

In iPhoto, the list of albums, folders, Events, slideshows, and more in the sidebar at the left side of the iPhoto window. The Source list grows as you add photos. The first item in the Source list is the iPhoto Library, which contains all your photos.
In the iMovie application, the file that contains a video clip you’re using in a project.

A feature of Mac OS X version 10.5 Leopard from Apple Inc. The Spaces feature lets you organize your windows into groups suited to specific purposes. For instance, you could set up a space primarily for business, and switch to a different space for playing games. You can create up to 16 spaces.
A feature of Macintosh computers that enables the computer to understand and carry out certain commands that you speak.

Searching software built into Macintosh computers. Spotlight builds a database of information about all the files on a computer by cataloging all items found when the computer is first started and any items added thereafter. When you type a search term into the Spotlight field, Spotlight checks its database for any files related to that term, and presents a list. Although the initial cataloging may take a few minutes, subsequent Spotlight searches appear instantaneously.
Static random-access memory. A type of memory that retains information as long as power is being supplied. Unlike DRAM, SRAM doesn’t require a new electrical charge every few milliseconds.

A feature of Mac OS X version 10.5 Leopard from Apple Inc. Stacks appear in the Dock and give you quick access to folders of files. When you click a stack, the files in the stack spring open in a fan or a grid.
A system preference on Macintosh computers that is used to designate an internal hard disk, external disk, partition, CD or DVD, or other device as the startup disk.
An Apple application that lets you post small notes, similar to Post-it notes, on your computer screen. In Mac OS X, Stickies is one of the widgets included with Dashboard.

A type of disk drive from Apple Inc. The original SuperDrive device was a high-capacity (1.44 MB) floppy disk drive. The current SuperDrive is a combination drive that can read and write (copy) to both CDs and DVDs.
In Mac OS 9 and earlier versions of the Mac OS, A folder that holds files necessary for the system’s operation, such as fonts and preferences. Mac OS X does not have a System Folder.

A set of software controls that come with Mac OS X. System Preferences are used to control many kinds of settings, such as desktop patterns, keyboard shortcuts, networking choices, power management, and more. System Preferences replaces the control panels found in versions of the Mac OS prior to Mac OS X.
An application that comes with Mac OS X. System Profiler provides detailed information about your computer’s installed software, built-in hardware, and attached devices.

An application that comes with Mac OS X. Terminal provides a window with a command line where you can type commands for the computer’s operating system to perform. Terminal is a type of program called a “terminal emulator” commonly found on UNIX-based computers.
A word-processing application that comes with Mac OS X.
A feature of Macintosh computers that enables you to have the computer read aloud highlighted text on the screen.
A small picture of an image, page, or video frame, which represents the larger original.
Trademarked name for Mac OS X version 10.4, the fifth major release of the operating system for Macintosh computers.

A computer backup device from Apple Inc. that works wirelessly with the Time Machine backup application in Mac OS X Leopard. Time Capsule is also an AirPort Extreme Base Station. Multiple computers can connect to a wireless network and perform wireless backups using a single Time Capsule.

An Apple file backup application that comes with Mac OS X version 10.5 Leopard. Time Machine creates regular backups of every file on your computer, including all data, software, and operating system files. Time Machine uses a “flying back through time” metaphor to show you images of previous versions of the active window or desktop so that you can retrieve and restore the version you want.
In the iMovie application, text you can add to your video project.
A special folder located at the end of the Dock on Macintosh computers. To remove an item from your disk, drag it to the Trash, and then choose Finder > Empty Trash or Finder > Secure Empty Trash.
Digital effects software available from Apple Inc. and used for feature films, broadcasts, and interactive games.
A standard developed by Apple Inc. for screen fonts.
A characteristic of products and services designed so that all people can use them, regardless of physical disabilities.

On Macintosh computers using Mac OS X, each person who uses the computer can have an individual account with a separate home folder. On a computer with multiple users, standard user accounts allow users to install software for their own use and change settings related to their own accounts. Each individual can adjust his or her own preferences without affecting other users. Users with standard user accounts can’t administer other accounts. Other account types include administrator, group, and guest.
See video compact disc.

An optical disc that holds more information than a CD, but less than a DVD. The video stored on a VCD is of a lower quality than video on a DVD, and similar to the quality of video on a VHS videotape. VCD video is encoded in MPEG-1 format. To view the contents of a VCD, use QuickTime Player and an optical drive in your computer or connected directly to your computer.
A portion of the computer’s hard disk that is used to augment the computer’s memory.
See VoiceOver.
See VoiceOver keys.

An alternate interface available on Macintosh computers for people with visual disabilities and others who need to hear what’s on the screen. VoiceOver describes aloud what appears on the screen, and speaks the text in documents and windows. Using VoiceOver, you control the computer primarily with the keyboard instead of the mouse.
The Control and Option keys, pressed together with other keys to enter VoiceOver commands, are called the VoiceOver keys, or “VO keys” for short. They are denoted as “VO” in documentation.
A mountable allocation of storage that behaves, from an individual user’s perspective, like a local hard disk, hard disk partition, or network volume.
See browser.
Apple software that lets you create your own Dashboard widgets using content on webpages.

Web-based Distributed Authoring and Versioning software. A live authoring environment that allows client users to check out webpages, make changes, and then check the pages back in to the site while the site is active and available to users.
See MobileMe Gallery.

A set of tools to help software developers display web content (such as webpages) within applications. WebKit simplifies the process of requesting content from an HTTP server on a network, and displaying the content for users to view.
WebObjects A development environment from Apple Inc. that enables web developers to quickly build web applications.
See webpage.
A page on the World Wide Web, viewable by anyone connected to the Internet and using a web browser.

A portion of content from a webpage that you can add to your own website. Many websites provide web widgets for you to post, including Internet videos, news headlines, stock quotes, photo streams, and more.

A mini-application on Macintosh computers. Widgets come with Dashboard as part of Mac OS X. Widgets include World Clock, Calculator, Calendar, Dictionary, Weather, and Stocks, among many others. Dashboard comes with several widgets already installed; more are available from the Apple website.
Wireless network software or hardware based on one of the 802.11 standards.
A set of tools for software developers creating applications for Mac OS X. The Xcode suite includes Interface Builder, WebObjects, and other tools.
An Apple application that allows an administrator to use the combined processing power of a group of networked computers to work on a single task.

A 64-bit cluster file system that enables multiple Mac desktop and Xserve computers to share RAID storage volumes over a high-speed network. Each computer can read and write directly to the centralized file system.
